thread.title: Bengals' Jeremy Hill: 'Winning all that matters'
thread.title_full: Bengals' Jeremy Hill: 'Winning all that matters'

title: Bengals' Jeremy Hill: 'Winning all that matters'
text:
Bengals' Jeremy Hill: 'Winning all that matters' Paul Dehner Jr. , pdehnerjr@enquirer.com 6:31 p.m. EDT October 1, 2015 Bengals notes on the mindset of Jeremy Hill, plus, a look at players on the mend in the Thursday injury report. Bengals running back Jeremy Hill breaks through the line of scrimmage in the first quarter. (Photo: The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar) 1 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Bengals running back Jeremy Hill hasn’t duplicated the phenomenal run from the final nine weeks of his rookie season. Quite the opposite, actually. 
Despite averaging only three yards per carry and spending the conclusion of the last two games watching Giovani Bernard take the snaps at running back he’s not letting personal struggles get in the way. 
“At this point I’m being a team guy,” Hill said. “I want the team to be successful and continue to win football games. At the end of the day if my numbers aren’t great or not astonishing or not helping people’s fantasy teams then, oh well, we are trying to win football games here. That’s all that matters at the end of the day.” 
He speaks the truth. Inevitably, however, a consistent running attack from Hill will be necessary to keep winning. Thus far, it hasn’t happened. Hill fumbled twice against San Diego, ending his day early. Last week he only managed 21 yards on 12 carries. Meanwhile, Giovani Bernard entered and racked up 49 yards on 13 rushes. Bengals' Film Session: Correcting a multitude of issues 
Bernard ranks second among NFL running backs in yards per carry at 5.7. Both Hill and Bernard have exactly 41 carries on the year. Bernard rushed for 235 yards on those and Hill 123. 
Bernard also has 12 receptions for 75 yards while Hill caught a single pass for two yards. Not hard to see why Bernard has been the last man standing at the conclusion of games. 
Last year, Hill rushed 222 times for 1,124 yards. That was 5.1 yards per rush. 
Theories to why Hill hasn’t transferred 2014 to 2015 stretch from tentative running to worrying too much about fumbling to not lining up behind Ryan Hewitt enough in the I-formation. 
He hears the support of his teammates noting he’s close to enjoying the one game to return the season to its desired track, but plans to keep plugging away with the same method for the breakthrough. 
“I’m just going to keep doing what I’m doing,” Hill said. “Keep pounding. Keep doing what got me here. Listen to the coaches, stick to the game plan, make sure I am assignment sound and keep working.” Bengals must terrorize Chiefs on third downs 
INJURY REPORT: Only one player wasn’t a full participant in Thursday’s practice for the Bengals. Safety George Iloka (ankle) missed practice for the second straight day. 
Adam Jones (elbow) returned after sitting out Wednesday. That’s particularly good news considering questions were abound whether Jones will be able to go Sunday against the Chiefs. He’s now trending in the correct direction. 
Elsewhere, defensive tackle Marcus Hardison (knee), corner Dre Kirkpatrick (shoulder), defensive tackle Pat Sims (hip) and offensive tackle Andre Smith (hip) all were full participants as well.
